awd_titl_txt: AitF: EXPL: Algorithmic Fluid Concentration Management for Programmable Microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
The miniaturization of technology has produced not only programmable microprocessor circuits, but also programmable lab-on-a-chip (PLoC) systems for microfluidics.  These systems control tiny fluid droplets, allowing precise mixing and testing, that can be developed into environmental monitors, malaria diagnostics, or blood tests for cancer cells.  As with microprocessors, programming a lab on a chip takes knowledge of what the chip can and cannot do, and a suitable language in which to express the commands.  This project 1) develops a theory of computational complexity for designing microfluidic devices that produce fluid mixtures with desired concentrations, 2) creates a domain-specific language  (including an Application Program Interface, or API and a compiler) for these devices, 3) fabricates and tests devices, and 4) explores the broader impacts of the ability to program complex biochemical reactions that include fluid concentration steps. The project results will make PLoC systems much easier to use, which the PIs will first demonstrate with students, including those from underrepresented groups, and then through tutorials presented at scientific meetings to promote the use of PLoC technologies among the broader scientific community. 

This project investigates the complexity and approximability of algorithms to generate one or more discrete fluid droplets having a desired concentration, e.g., a sample diluted to 10%, 15%, etc., with objectives such as minimizing the number of dilution steps, minimizing waste, minimizing reactant usage, etc. These algorithms will be generalized to produce of a stream of droplets having desired time-dependent concentrations. Meanwhile, a collection of representative PLoCs will be designed and fabricated on-site, along with a domain-specific language and compiler, which will allow the PLoCs to be programmed using high-level software. The algorithms developed in the course of this project will be integrated into an API that can be called from the domain-specific language. This will enable users to specify biochemical reactions that include fluid concentration generation subroutines (which are performed automatically). The system will be validated by executing these biochemical reactions using the PLoCs that have been fabricated on-site. Upon successful completion of the project, PLoC design files along with the domain-specific language specification and compiler, documentation, and tutorial material, will be released publicly to encourage other scientists to use this platform and approach to increase productivity and reduce human error in their respective laboratories.

por.por_cntn:
Summary:

In the area of algorithms, the research focussed on developing models and algorithms for designing fluid mixing chips. For droplet-based chips, the PIs developed mathematical foundations for the theory of fluid mixing, showing connections to some problems in number theory. Building on these connections, they designed a characterizations of vectors of input droplets that can be perfectly mixed using such chips, together with a polynomial-time algorithm that produces such chips. They have also developed an efficient algorithm for designing mixing chips for given target vectors. This algorithm generalizes and outperforms existing algorithms. The PIs also worked on the flow-based model, where they developed a technique for simulating flow mixing in mixing grids. The essence of this technique is to simulate the fluid density contour, using appropriate physics formulas, by a simple shapen that can be efficiently updated along the pipe segments. The resulting algorithm greatly outperforms comsol-based simulations, facilitating the design of larger grid, which can be used to produce a wider range of fluid densities.

Intellectual Merit:

All earlier work on designing algorithms for designing droplet-based mixing chips focussed on desining heuristics, and on combinatorial/graph-theoretic aspects of this problem. The PIs showed that the core challenges are in fact of number-theoretic nature, thus opening a new direction towards further progress in this area. The PI's formal approach to algorithm design, including defining appropriate performance measures, establishing worst-case performance bounds, and proofs of correctness, further confirmed by experimental analysis, will contribute to the maturing of this field. The PIs work on simulating fluid mixing in fluid-based mixing grids shows that the tools and ideas from discrete algorithmics (including some topological properties of planar graphs), can produce algorithms that are much faster than fluid-dynamics software, and produce results that are sufficiently accurate in some contexts. 

Broader Impact:

The mathematical properties of droplet-based mixing chips and algorithmic techniques for designing such chips, that were developed in the course of this project, will contribute to further growth of the field and to improved tools for designing mixing chips, which are critical compoments of various microfluidic devices. On the purely theoretical side, the remaining number-theoretic questions are expected to inspire some work in number theory, where they have not yet been studied. This project has also contributed to training of graduate students. One student (Hispanic) has already completed his PhD, and one other student (female) is continuing her research towards her dissertation. This project also provided training for a number of undergraduate students, several of whom co-authored peer-reviewed publications with the PI and/or Co-PIs.

The PI interacted with industrial players in the microfluidics industry and standardization bodies, including the Microfluidics Consortium, the Microfluidics Association, and the Modularity Group within the Microfluidics Association. The PI participated in a series of biologically-themed Hack-a-thons organized by undergraduate students enrolled at UC Riverside and made presentations that included research results from this project to UC Riverside student organizations. Several student supervised by the PI provided several years of training for K-12 teachers, leading the eventual conferal of California State supplemental authorization for Computer Science Education. Lastly, the PI mentored one pre-tenure faculty member who successfully attained tenure during the final year of the project.
